contextId.information: This rhetorical question would have been used to show the people's need of Yahweh. AT: "We need Yahweh. He is the one who brought us ... Egypt." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is Yahweh, who brought us ... Egypt?

contextId.information: God uses this question to tell the people of Israel that other nations continue to worship their own gods. They do not change and worship other gods. AT: "You will see that no nation has ever exchanged ... gods." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has a nation exchanged gods ... gods?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to indicate that Israel should not have become plunder. AT: "But now he has become plunder" or "So he should not have become plunder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]
contextId.quote: So why has he become plunder?

contextId.information: God uses this question to rebuke his people for saying that they have not worshiped the Baals. AT: "You lie when you say, 'I ... have not walked after the Baals.' (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you say, 'I ... have not walked after the Baals'?

contextId.information: With this question God implies that people should ask the gods they worship to help them. He uses this irony to show that he is angry that they worship other gods. AT: "You should ask the gods you made to help you." or "You do not ask the gods you made to help you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: Yet where are the gods that you made for yourselves?

contextId.information: God uses this question to rebuke the people of Israel for accusing him of doing wrong. AT: "Israel, you claim that I was wrong when I did not rescue you when you called on me, even though you continue to sin against me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: So why do you accuse me of doing wrong? All of you have sinned against me

contextId.information: God uses this question to introduce the idea of remembering things that are important to someone. AT "You know that a virgin would never forget to put on her jewelry, and a bride would never forget to put on her veils." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will a virgin forget her jewelry, a bride her veils?

contextId.information: Yahweh is scolding the Israelites because they changed from one kingdom to another for help but did not rely on God for help. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Why do you treat so very lightly this change in your ways?

contextId.information: God uses this question to show the Israelites that because they worshiped idols, they should not think that God would allow them to return to him. AT: "yet now you want to return to me." or "yet you think that I should allow you to come back to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: and would you return to me?

contextId.information: God uses this question to rebuke his people for calling out to him and saying these things. AT: "You call out to me: 'My father ... end?'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not just now called to me: 'My father ... end?'

contextId.information: These questions express the people's hope that God will not be angry with them forever. AT: "Surely he will not always be angry with me to the end." or "Surely you will not be angry with us forever." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he always be angry? Will he always keep his wrath to the end?

contextId.information: God uses this question to draw Jeremiah's attention to Israel's faithlessness. It can be translated as a command or a statement. AT: "See how faithless Israel is to me" or "You see how faithless Israel is to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you see what faithless Israel has done?

contextId.information: Jeremiah uses this question to emphasize that what Yahweh really wants is faithfulness. AT: "you want people to be faithful." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: do your eyes not look for faithfulness

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he has no reason to pardon these people. AT: "Because of the things that they do, I cannot pardon these people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why should I pardon these people

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that the things that they are doing are so bad that he will no have mercy and stop himself from punishing them. AT: "Because they do these things, I will punish them ... I will certainly get revenge for myself against them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: So should I not punish them ... and should I not avenge myself on a nation that is like this?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that none of the people of Israel would listen to him even after they survived the attack of their enemies. AT: "There is no one left for me to speak to and warn who might listen." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: To whom should I declare and warn so they will listen

contextId.information: "They committed terrible sins, and they were not ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Were they ashamed when they committed abominations?

contextId.information: These questions expect a positive answer to make the point that God knows the sins they are committing. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You steal, kill, and commit adultery. You swear ... and walk after other gods whom you have not known." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you steal, kill, and commit adultery? Do you swear ... and walk after other gods whom you have not known?

contextId.information: This question expects a positive answer to make the point that God knows the hypocrisy of their words and actions. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Then you come and stand ... so you can do all of these abominations." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Then do you come and stand ... so you can do all of these abominations?

contextId.information: This question expects a positive answer to make the point that God knows what they think about Yahweh's temple. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "This house, which carries my name, is a den of bandits in your eyes!" or "You act as though you think this house, which is called by my name, should be a place where bandits can go to hide!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is this house, which carries my name, a den of bandits in your eyes?

contextId.information: This question expects a negative answer. It can be expressed as a statement. AT: "They are not really provoking me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are they truly provoking me?

contextId.information: AT: "You know that when someone falls, he gets back up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]]).
contextId.quote: Does anyone fall and not get up?

contextId.information: "Why do you say, we are wise! And we have the law of Yahweh?" AT: "You should not say that you are wise and that you have the law of Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you say, "We are wise, for the law of Yahweh is with us"?

contextId.information: AT: "We should not stay here." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are we sitting here

contextId.information: Jeremiah does not expect an answer to this question. It is more like a statement. AT: "Everyone should fear you, king of the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who does not fear you, king of the nations?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that the people Judah no longer have a right to be in his temple. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "My beloved one, the one who has had so many wicked intentions, should not be in my house."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why is my beloved one, the one who has had so many wicked intentions, in my house?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question implies that he would not be able to run with horses. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "you will never compete well against horses." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how can you compete against horses?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize this his people are surround by their enemies. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "My prized possession has become a speckled bird and other birds of prey go against her all around" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has not my prized possession become a speckled bird, that other birds of prey go against her all around?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is used to state an example of something that is impossible. This question can be written as a statement. Also, the missing words can be added to the second phrase. AT: "The people of Cush cannot change their skin color and a leopard cannot change its spots." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: Can the people of Cush change their skin color, or a leopard change its spots?

contextId.information: AT: "My pain is ongoing and my wound incurable. I cannot be healed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why is my pain ongoing and my wound incurable, refusing to be healed?

contextId.information: The people use this question to ridicule Jeremiah because the things that he said had not yet happened. AT: "Where are the things that Yahweh told you would happen?" or "The things that Yahweh told you would happen have not happened." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is the word of Yahweh?

contextId.information: This question stands for a statement. AT: "Nowhere on earth has anyone ever heard of such a thing like this." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Ask the nations, who has ever heard of such a thing as this?

contextId.information: Jeremiah asks this question to emphasize that good actions should not be repaid with bad things. AT: "Disaster from them should not be my reward for being good to them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will disaster from them really be my reward for being good to them?

contextId.information: Jeremiah uses this question to complain that there was no good reason for him to be born. AT: "There was no reason for me to be born only to see troubles and agony ... shame." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why is it that I came out from the womb to see troubles and agony ... shame?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke Jehoiakim for his expensive palace. AT: "Having a cedar palace does not make you a good king." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is this what makes you a good king, that you wanted to have boards of cedar

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke Jehoiakim for not following the example of his father, King Josiah. AT: "This is what it means to know me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is this not what it means to know me?

contextId.information: Jehoiachin is spoken of as a pot that was completely worthless and not liked by anyone. The questions emphasize that he has no value or friends. AT: "Jehoiachin is as useless as a broken vessel and no one is happy with him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is this a despised and shattered vessel? Is this man Jehoiachin a pot that pleases no one?

contextId.information: AT: "I am a God who is both nearby and far away." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Am I only a God nearby ... and not also a God far away?

contextId.information: AT: "This should not continue, prophets who declare lies which they themselves have made up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How long will this go on, prophets who prophesy lies from their minds, and who prophesy from the deceit in their hearts?

contextId.information: AT: "Straw and grain are two totally different things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What does straw have to do with grain?

contextId.information: AT: "My word is like fire: consuming and powerful," says Yahweh, "and like a hammer that shatters a rock into pieces." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Is not my word like fire?—this is Yahweh's declaration—and like a hammer that shatters a rock into pieces?

contextId.information: This question is meant to function as a statement AT: "There is no declaration." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What declaration?

contextId.information: AT: "you are to be punished." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: should you yourselves be free from punishment?

contextId.information: This is a rebuke. AT: "You should not have prophesied in Yahweh's name that his temple would be destroyed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why have you prophesied in Yahweh's name and said that this house will become like Shiloh and this city will become desolate, with no inhabitant?

contextId.information: AT: "Hezekiah, king of Judah and the people of Judah did not put Micah to death." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did Hezekiah king of Judah and all of Judah put him to death?

contextId.information: AT: "You will die, you and your people, by the sword, famine, and plague, just as I have declared, if you do not serve the king of Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why will you die—you and your people—by the sword, famine, and plague, just as I have declared about the nation that refuses to serve the king of Babylon?

contextId.information: "This entire city will be destroyed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why should this city become a ruin?

contextId.information: Yahweh asked a question here to make the people think about why they are asking him for help now. AT: "Do not call for help for your injury." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you call for help for your injury?

contextId.information: Yahweh is speaking tenderly, trying to comfort the people. These questions can be translated as statements. AT: "Ephraim is my precious child. He is my dear, delightful son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is not Ephraim my precious child? Is he not my dear, delightful son?

contextId.information: Yahweh is telling his people that he is becoming impatient with them because they are not obeying him. AT: "Do not hesitate to start obeying me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How long will you waver, faithless daughter?

contextId.information: Zekekiah uses a question to rebuke Jeremiah. AT: "It is wrong for you to continue prophesying and saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you prophesy and say

contextId.information: Yahweh wants Jeremiah to think deeply about what the people have said. AT: "You should have noticed what this people are really saying when they said, 'The ... them.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not considered what this people has declared when they said, 'The ... them'?

contextId.information: Yahweh is telling Israel to listen carefully to his rebuke. AT: "You must certainly receive this correction and listen to my words." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will you not receive correction and listen to my words?

contextId.information: Jehoiakim uses this question to emphasize that Jeremiah should not have written that the king of Babylon would come and attack. AT: "You should not have written" or "You were wrong to write." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why have you written on it

contextId.information: Jeremiah uses this question to emphasize that he has not done anything wrong. AT: "I have not done anything wrong to you ... prison." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How have I sinned against you ... prison?

contextId.information: Jeremiah uses this question to emphasize that the other prophets were lying but that he had done nothing wrong because he had told the truth. AT: "Your prophets who prophesied ... against this land, were obviously wrong, but now it is clear that I was telling you the truth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Where are your prophets, the ones who prophesied ... against this land

contextId.information: Jeremiah uses this question to express his belief that the king will kill him if he answers truthfully. AT: "If I tell you the truth, you will certainly kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If I answer you, will you not certainly kill me?

contextId.information: "Certainly, you should realize that Baalis king of the people of Ammon sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to murder you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you realize that Baalis king of the people of Ammon sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to murder you?

contextId.information: "You should not allow him to kill you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why should he kill you

contextId.information: Yahweh uses these questions to rebuke the people for doing things that cause him to punish them. AT: "You are doing ... yourselves. You are causing ... and babies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are you doing ... yourselves? Why are you causing ... and babies?

contextId.information: Yahweh rebukes the people for not thinking about the wicked behavior of their ancestors and how Yahweh punished them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Think about what happened to your ancestors and the kings of Judah and their wives when they did wicked things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Have you forgotten the wickedness committed by your ancestors and the wickedness committed by the kings of Judah and their wives?

contextId.information: AT: "You do hope for great things for yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But are you hoping for great things for yourself?

contextId.information: The word "I" here refer to Yahweh. Yahweh asks this sarcastic question to emphasize what he has said regarding the nation of Egypt has come true. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What am I seeing here?

contextId.information: AT: "Egypt rises like the Nile." Yahweh asks this question to draw the listener's attention to the nation of Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is this who rises like the Nile

contextId.information: AT: "Your god Apis has run away." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why has your god Apis run away?

contextId.information: AT: "No longer can you say, 'We are soldiers, powerful fighting men.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you say, 'We are soldiers, powerful fighting men'?

contextId.information: AT: "For you used to laugh at and mock My people in the kingdom of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For did Israel not become an object for laughter to you?

contextId.information: AT: "You should not be so proud because you really are not strong." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are you proud of your strength?

contextId.information: "Those who harvest grapes always leave some on the vines." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If grape harvesters came

contextId.information: AT: "Certainly, you must be aware that you will personally experience my punishment for your sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you yourself think you will go without punishment?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the question to point out the smallness of humans. AT: " No one is like me, no one orders me around". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For who is like me, and who will summon me?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the question to show no one can defeat him. "Shepherd" here is a metaphor for "king," "ruler." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: What shepherd is able to resist me?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the question to point out the smallness of humans. AT: "No one is like me, no one orders me around." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: who is like me, and who will summon me?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the question to show that no leader is able to come against him or defeat him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What shepherd is able to resist me?
